page.title: 17Public Houses
page.content: As long as the soldiers were in the town, Hythe had many public houses but when the army left many closed but there are still plenty left from the smallest, the{Three Mariners,}to the large{Red Lion.} One of the oldest is {The Bell,}probably the ancient harbour pub but the only proof are smugglers tales. Beneath the floor is a tunnel; a legendary hiding place for casks of Brandy. In the attic is a hook that was used to hoist them out. Several of the pubs in the High Street are first heard of in the sixteenth century.{The Swan,}built in 1506 was an eighteenth century posting inn with a milestone set in the front wall.{The White Hart}has a seventeenth century exterior but looks older inside. There are no cellars which could mean it was once on the water front.
